nd

Exactly, which is exactly why you should be=
 humble when you ship your code
and open it up.  Assume that people will us=
e it in ways you didn't think of,
and make it possible for them to do so in=
 ways that you control (always an
interesting exercise, by the way, it forc=
es you to think out of the box and
to break your habits).

Michael showed a=
 pretty compelling case where the vendor forgot to make
their methods virtu=
al, and I've seen this mistake and more general ones so
many times in dozen=
s of API's and libraries I wish people locked down their
code a lot less.

=
Real life example:  a programmer on my team once had to do "#define private=

public" in order to use a certain functionality.  There was simply no othe=
r
choice.  That's exactly what I meant above by "keeping control": if you o=
pen
your code in ways that you choose, you, the library author, remain in
c=
ontrol and remove the need for this kind of ugly hack.


Adding functionali=
ty without a clear use case is a recipe for bloated
> APIs that don't work =
particularly well.


I don't see why, if they are carefully designed.  Docu=
ment the extension
points, and draw a clear line between what is exposed an=
d will be supported
and what might change from one release to the next.

Wi=
thout this mindset, frameworks such as Spring or Eclipse would never
exist.=

s

rator,

l because it's all just streams (or

built into the core libraries to
